No portion 01 the Institutas presents so clearly the contrast between modern and ancient law, or brings out more vividly the exclusive regard paid to agnatio relationship in primitive society. While pointing out the injustice which this system of succession entailed upon many classes, especially emancipated children and de- scendants or collaterale who traced their kinship with the deceased through a female, Justinian takes occasion to describe briefly the extent to which a remedy had been supplied by the bonorum possessio intestati of the Praetor, a subject more explicitly treated in Title 9, and also various disconnected changes made in the law by earlier Emperors as well as by himself.
